item.title: This Cool Assassin's Creed Post-Launch Feature Won't Be Coming To Shadows
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

One of the big draws of Assassin's Creed games has been its attention to historical detail, especially when you were given a chance to soak it all in via the Discovery Tour mode from previous games. Sadly, this feature won't be coming to Assassin's Creed Shadows, as Ubisoft confirmed that it has no plans to offer a "Japan Discovery Tour" as post-launch DLC.

"We do not currently have a 'Japan Discovery Tour' like we had for 'Viking Age' in the works," Assassin's Creed Shadows producer Andr√© said in a Reddit AMA.

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: Assassin's Creed Shadows Gives Players Two Unique Ways to Play.

Assassin's Creed Shadows does have a Historical Codex that provides a wealth of content to read through, but it doesn't quite compare to how Discovery Tour allows you to explore the game's world and learn more about the history of that specific era. If you're unfamiliar with it, Discovery Tour was an optional mode introduced in Assassin's Creed Origins, with Assassin's Creed Odyssey and Assassin's Creed Valhalla also receiving the mode as post-launch content.

The mode stripped out all combat from the Assassin's Creed games, giving you free rein to wander around at your leisure or engage in a guided tour. For example, Assassin's Creed Odyssey had dozens of guided tours covering themes like ancient Greek art and philosophy, while Assassin's Creed Valhalla's Viking Age mode had players assume the roles of various characters and take on quests that were designed to educate them about life in Norway and Anglo-Saxon England.

While Assassin's Creed Shadows won't be offering any post-launch history lessons, fans can look forward to its new expansion when it arrives next month. Ubisoft also spoke about how it is planning to dig deep into the secret war between Templars and Assassins, and it looks like the live-action Netflix series adaptation is starting to gather momentum.

item.title: Switch 2 Is Adding This Hard-To-Find GameCube Game To Switch Online Library
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Nintendo has announced that Chibi-Robo will be the latest GameCube game to come to the Nintendo Switch 2's classic library as part of the Nintendo Switch Online + Expansion Pack subscription.

The rare and expensive title will be added to Switch Online's GameCube library on Thursday, August 21, 2025, bringing the collection to five games.

Originally released in 2006 in North America, Chibi-Robo is a platform-adventure game where you play as the titular diminutive hero tasked with helping out the Sanderson household. As you complete tasks, you gain "Happy Points" in your goal to become the top-ranked "Super Chibi-Robo" in the world. But over time, you will also be helping out the Sanderson family tackle their own personal problems.

Although Chibi-Robo only achieved modest sales when originally released, it's become a rare cult classic that had never previously been re-released, while the copies of the game often fetch high prices. In our original review, we said, "Despite the monotonous and occasionally tiresome gameplay, the great cast of characters and offbeat sense of humor manage to make Chibi-Robo a compelling and ultimately enjoyable experience."

It was the only home console release for the series, with subsequent instalments, such as Chibi-Robo: Park Patrol and Chibi-Robo! Zip Lash, developed for the Nintendo DS and 3DS respectively. The latter was considered a commercial failure, including even in Japan.

Nintendo has previously confirmed that other GameCube classics like Super Mario Sunshine, Fire Emblem: Path of Radiance, and Pokemon Colosseum will be added to the Switch Online service in the future.

Other perks from the Switch Online + Expansion Pack subscriptions have included Switch 2 edition upgrades, although this has so far been limited to The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild and The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom for those who own the original games on Switch 1.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Battlefield 6 Dev Explains Why Only Portal Mode Is Getting A Server Browser
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Battlefield 6 fans are sharing plenty of feedback--both good and bad--following the game's first open-beta weekend, and one recurring theme has seen players requesting a BF6 server browser with persistent servers. Producer David Sirland has responded to fans on social media, explaining exactly why DICE only has a server brower for Portal mode.

In response to a player asking for a way to matchmake with larger groups of players, without having to rejoin after every game, Sirland said that the Portal server browser "is basically enabling that." While Portal's main selling points are user-created game modes and custom experiences, Sirland says that the mode still fulfills the main function of a server browser, even if players may have to filter out the verified servers from the custom experiences.

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: Battlefield 6 - Official Multiplayer Gameplay Reveal Trailer

"The combination of the pool of the persistent servers and the spun-up ones is not very useful," Sirland explains. "Matchmaking servers spin up in seconds (get filled with players), and spin down after game is over. That couple of seconds plus when servers lose a lot of players mid-game is the only time you can join, which makes it a tricky combination (and full of queuing to join issues)."

"We think the current setup gives us the best of both worlds, as you can choose to go spin up a server through regular matchmaking, or find an existing server that is already running, or create your own as well," Sirland says of the decision to limit the server browser to Portal mode. He adds that DICE will be testing the browser soon, allowing players to check out the new system for themselves.

In another reply, Sirland explains the lack of persistent servers in standard matchmaking, explaining that the current system allows for a lot more flexibility between maps and game modes--which means shorter waits for matchmaking.

"That is to allow for playlists of varying size (max players) and modes," Sirland says. "For example, you can play the 'Yellow maps' playlist that contains Siege of Cairo and Iberian Offensive (any mode). Then let's say I picked the playlist called 'Domination Bonanza,' which includes all three open-beta maps. We can play together when our respective playlists overlap. As in when your "yellow map" plays Domination, for example. That way we pack servers much more effectively and can allow for more modes and max sizes to coexist in the same playlists.

"Stuff like Rush, that for some maps play 48 players, for others 32 players, and for some 64 players, we want to be able to put in playlists too," Sirland continues. "This is not possible in the old system of persistent servers as the max-players count is locked (or we'd have to kick players, for example)."

Sirland hasn't specified when players will be able to test the Portal browser for themselves, but the next round of the BF6 open beta is due to kick off very soon on August 14. To check out the second leg of the beta for yourself, our Battlefield 6 open beta breakdown has all the info you need to get started.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Battlefield 6 Matchmaking Does Not Prioritize Skill
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Battlefield 6's open beta gave players a taste of the multiplayer package, and people have since voiced questions and concerns about the matchmaking algorithm and specifically around how skill may be factored in.

According to producer David Sirland, Battlefield 6's matchmaking system works the same as past games and what was in the beta is representative of what's being prepared for launch in October. The system prioritizes ping and "time-to-game" ahead of most everything else, including skill, Sirland said.

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: Battlefield 6 - Official Multiplayer Gameplay Reveal Trailer

"Skill is a factor, but far down the list," he said.

Battlefield 6's larger-scale modes "need a spread of skill to work well," Sirland added. "The sandbox needs many different types of skill to function well, and that's also why the matchmaker team balances to make the teams even as part of that process," he explained.

Skill-based matchmaking (SBMM) is a hot-button issue in a variety of competitive games, including Call of Duty. Activision is historically less transparent about its matchmaking priorities, but the company has said it uses SBMM because the data shows fewer players quit under a skill-based system than they do without it.

Fans will get to try Battlefield 6 again soon with the second weekend of the open beta kicking off on August 14. For the second weekend, Battlefield Studios is adding more maps and modes.

Battlefield 6 launches in full on October 10 for PS5, Xbox Series X|S, and PC. That's about a month before Activision's Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 is reportedly set to launch on November 14.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Battlefield 6 Devs Are Looking Into "Unexpectedly Fast" Time-To-Kill Reports From Open Beta
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Battlefield 6's record-breaking first open beta has come and gone, and now the developers are starting to sift through player feedback and bug reports. One of the issues in the crosshairs is the reported "super bullet" causing unexpectedly fast time-to-kill rates.

BF6's principal game designer Florian Le Bihan took to X following the end of the open beta to ask players for videos of "suspected super bullet/unexpectedly fast TTD" bugs. A number of players have reported having this issue in the Battlefield beta, with some streamers even experiencing the issue live on stream. The unusually quick TTD (time to death or time to down) bug causes some players to be downed in just a few shots, and sometimes even when behind cover.

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: Battlefield 6 - Official Multiplayer Gameplay Reveal Trailer

Players were quick to provide examples of the suspected bug, with some speculating that the server was slow to apply damage that had already been received, causing the full amount of damage to be applied to the player all at once after a short delay. Players have also reported taking damage or failing to heal when they should be at full health, including immediately after respawning--though this bug appears to only impact the health-bar UI and not players' actual hit points.

While some player's TTD issues were put down to regular lag due to a poor internet connection, others have shared videos of the suspected bug in question. Le Bihan later updated to thank players for sharing their footage, saying he's now been sent "a bunch of good videos" to investigate the issue.

With the first open-beta weekend concluded, players have taken to social media to share their thoughts on the preview, both good and bad. The beta reached a huge number of people, and the developers at DICE no doubt have a big job ahead of them combing through player feedback and bug reports ahead of the game's release on October 10.

Players will have a chance to check out more Battlefield 6 maps and different modes when the open beta returns for a second weekend on August 14. For more, check out GameSpot's Battlefield 6 open beta breakdown.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Lady Gaga Is Joining Roblox's Dress To Impress For Special Event
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Dress to Impress debuted on Roblox nearly two years ago and it's become one of the most popular experiences on the platform. Now, it may reach even further heights because Lady Gaga is coming to Dress to Impress for a special event this week.

Under the rules of Dress to Impress, players are invited to create outfits based on specific themes, and the top three winners are chosen by votes from other players. For this event, the theme is Mayhem, the most recent album from Lady Gaga.

Starting on August 16, players will be able to compete in Mayhem-themed challenges and earn Lady Gaga-related items and clothing. Style Showdown will also feature a challenge based on Lady Gaga's song Zombieboy. A lucky few may even get a chance to meet Lady Gaga in-game as she judges an outfit competition for herself.

Outside of the Lady Gaga event, there's an assortment of free outfits and accessories that can be claimed by Dress to Impress players in August. Dress to Impress isn't the only Roblox game that's become a breakout success. Grow a Garden's popularity has only continued to rise and its most recent update added cooking to the game. Earlier this week, YouTube celebrated 1 trillion views for Roblox-related videos over the last two decades.

There are currently no available deals

GameSpot may get a commission from retail offers.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
